title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act may be cited as the "America's Border Security Act of 2007" and includes provisions related to technological assets. The "America's Border Security Act of 2007" aims to increase the availability of Department of Defense equipment, such as unmanned aerial vehicles and surveillance equipment, to assist in preventing illegal immigration at the international land borders of the United States. A report detailing the current use of this equipment must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Defense must submit a report to Congress detailing the current use of Department of Defense equipment for surveillance at the US international land borders, assessing risks, and outlining plans to increase equipment usage. Additionally, the report must describe the types of equipment and support to be provided by the Secretary of Defense for a 1-year period. During a 1-year pilot program, the Secretary of Homeland Security will test unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance along the Canada-US international border. No changes to the prohibition on using the Army or Air Force as a posse comitatus. Appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012 to carry out the program. SEC. 3. INFRASTRUCTURE.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will construct roads, acquire barriers, and facilities for border control. Quarterly progress reports to Congress required. Appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012.

SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct additional ports of entry along the international land borders of the United States and make necessary improvements to existing ports of entry. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other agencies for clear and secure communication. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the US international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to carry out this mandate, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 7. SURVEILLANCE TECHNOLOGIES PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico, ensuring continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must develop an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to monitor each mile of the international borders with Canada and Mexico. This program includes assessing aerial surveillance technologies, consulting with the Secretary of Defense on deploying technologies, and consulting with the FAA on safety and airspace. The aerial surveillance program developed by the Secretary of Homeland Security will use various technologies to monitor the international borders of the United States, consulting with the FAA on safety and airspace coordination. The Secretary of Homeland Security may continue using aerial surveillance technologies for border security, considering previous experiences, cost-effectiveness, technical complexity, liability, safety, and privacy concerns. A report to Congress is required within 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a report to Congress within 180 days regarding the utilization of aerial surveillance technologies for border security. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of an Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program to procure technologies for border security, including unmanned aerial vehicles, cameras, sensors, and radar coverage to create a "virtual fence" along the international borders of the United States. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program ensures that technologies are integrated and function cohesively, cameras do not require manual operation, views and positions are not fixed, surveillance videos can be viewed at designated centers, and a standard process is used for data collection. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program ensures that surveillance data can be viewed at designated centers, a standard process is used for data collection, future technology upgrades can be integrated with existing systems, performance measures are developed to evaluate effectiveness, and plans are made to streamline site selection processes. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program aims to streamline site selection, validation, and environmental assessment processes for installing surveillance technology infrastructure. Standards are developed to utilize existing structures and deploy nonpermanent surveillance platforms to enhance border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to report to Congress within one year of the program's implementation. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit a report to Congress on the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including a description of the program and any recommendations for improvement. Standards will be developed to evaluate contractors providing goods or services for the program, with reviews conducted by the Inspector General of the Department. The Inspector General of the Department reviews new contracts over $5,000,000 for compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. Findings are reported to the Secretary of Homeland Security promptly for submission to the Committee. The Inspector General reviews contracts over $5,000,000 for compliance. The Secretary must report findings to the Senate and House Committees and describe steps taken in response. Authorization of appropriations is provided. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on personnel to fulfill these requirements. Training must be provided for border and transportation security personnel. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide ongoing training for agents, inspectors, and support staff to utilize new technologies and maintain acceptable proficiency levels to protect the borders of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide ongoing training for agents, inspectors, and support staff to utilize new technologies and maintain acceptable proficiency levels to protect the borders of the United States. Additionally, there is a focus on implementing a National Border Security Plan. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to prepare a National Border Security Plan annually by January 31 and consult with various agencies. The plan must include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern or southern border. Port security coordinators may be established at these entry points. Establish port security coordinators at each northern or southern border entry point to assist with vulnerability assessments and plan preparation.
